title: Facebook penalises Netanyahu page over hate speech violation
text:
Israeli PM has denied writing inflammatory post about ‘Arabs who want to destroy us all’

Facebook says it has imposed sanctions on Benjamin Netanyahu’s page on the site because of a violation of its hate speech policy.

The company said on Thursday it had suspended the page’s bot – or automated chat function – for 24 hours. The Israeli prime minister’s page had called on voters to prevent the establishment of a government composed of “Arabs who want to destroy us all – women, children and men”, provoking uproar among opposition politicians.

In an interview with Kan Reshet Bet radio, Netanyahu denied writing the post, which was subsequently removed, saying it was a staffer’s mistake.

Netanyahu is fighting for his political survival ahead of elections next week and has been shoring up nationalist votes with incendiary language and hardline promises.

On Tuesday he announced he would annex large swaths of occupied Palestinian territories if he was re-elected, a move that for decades has been considered an endgame scenario for Palestinians’ aspirations of statehood.

Last week he drew outrage from opposition parties with a push for last-minute legislation that would allow party officials to bring cameras to polling stations.

His critics labelled it a naked attempt to depress turnout among Israel’s Arab population, as it could intimidate many into staying away. They also pointed out that it could serve to energise Netanyahu’s base of rightwing voters due to his warnings – so far unfounded – that the election could be stolen.

Netanyahu insisted that he was only interested in protecting the integrity of the vote and preventing fraud. On Wednesday a bill allowing parties to place cameras in polling stations failed in the Knesset.

He has used similar tactics in the past, including warning on election day in 2015 that Israeli Arabs were voting in “droves”, a comment for which he later apologised.
